title: Cat. 28  Courtyard, Chelsea Hospital, 1888
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 281888Way: 23  
Levy: 36  
Lithograph with stumping  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, upper left on facade  
One state; image size: 215 × 162 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 6  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 218  
Stone: probably erased in 1888; certainly by 1896  
Lifetime Exhibitions: Chicago 1900b (no. 20)

Whistler probably drew this view of a courtyard and porticos within the vast compound of the Royal Hospital in Chelsea when he was living nearby during the summer of 1888. Commissioned by Charles II and designed by Christopher Wren in 1682, the complex of buildings was intended from the outset to house war veterans. The lithograph captures two “Chelsea pensioners,” as these retired soldiers were called, seated on a bench in the sun, while a small group of neighborhood children play in the foreground. The composition, focused on the old doorway, its surrounding columns, and the courtyards glimpsed in the distance, repeats a motif frequently employed by the artist in the pastels and etchings he made in Venice in 1879/80.

Whistler drew Courtyard, Chelsea Hospital directly on stone rather than on transfer paper. The stone appears to have been coarsely grained, providing a difficult drawing surface; as a result, impressions are rather spotty and lacking in clarity. The stump was used minimally in the darkest vertical shadow of the door. Whistler was probably disappointed with the image, judging from the small number of prints pulled and from the fact that the stone seems to have been erased almost immediately after proofing. In the 1905 edition of his catalogue, T. R. Way reported only six proofs of this subject; however, fourteen impressions (four signed, ten unsigned) were listed in the 1903 inventory of the artist’s estate.

Chicago: AIC, cream wove paper (316 × 196 mm), signed; MWC, cream wove paper (316 × 196 mm). Glasgow: HAG, cream wove paper (316 × 196 mm). London: BM, grayish white chine (228 × 163 mm) mounted on white plate paper (372 × 267 mm). Washington: FGA, grayish white chine (228 × 162 mm) mounted on white plate paper (381 × 280 mm); NGA, cream wove paper (315 × 196 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi
